misconceptions.inferred_category_name: None (logic matches intended array shift semantics)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to right-shift an array by 1 with wrap-around, you must save the last element, copy each element from index i-1 to i going backwards, then place the saved last element into index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No meaningful conceptual gap: this matches Java’s actual execution model (arrays are mutable, assignment overwrites, so shifting must be done from the end to avoid overwriting values needed later).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error: produces correct shifted array for N>0; for N=0 it prints an empty shifted line, which is reasonable/consistent with the prompt.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No misconception detected (correct in-place right shift with wrap-around)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes they must save the last element, shift the rest from right-to-left to avoid overwriting, then put the saved last element into index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No conceptual gap: this matches Java’s actual array assignment semantics and avoids overwriting by iterating from the end toward the start.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; produces correct shifted output for N>0 and prints nothing after 'Shifted:' for N=0, which is acceptable unless the spec requires otherwise.
